title-group.article-title: Modeling Credit Contagion via the Updating of Fragile Beliefs

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2015 The Society for Financial Studies

abstract.p: We propose an equilibrium model for defaultable bonds that are subject to contagion risk. Contagion arises because agents with "fragile beliefs" are uncertain about the underlying economic state and its probability. Estimation on sovereign European credit default swaps (CDS) data shows that agents require a time-varying risk premium for bearing state uncertainty. The model outperforms affine specifications with the same number of state variables, suggesting that there are important nonlinearities in credit spreads that are captured by our model. Contagion drives most of the variation in CDS spreads, especially before the crisis. However, economic fundamentals account for a significant fraction during the crisis.

p.mixed-citation: Examples include "Contagion fears hit bonds, euro," Wall Street Journal, November 30, 2010; "The Euro crisis: A contagious Irish disease," The Economist, November 25, 2010; "Contagion fears push the Euro to fresh low," The Financial Times, November 29, 2010.

For example, John Cochrane writes, "The bailout is being justified on grounds of containing 'contagion.' This is nonsense. The notion is that news of an Irish restructuring would scare investors in Spanish bonds, who would start looking at Spain's ability to repay its debts and then demand higher interest rates. But haven't investors in Spanish bonds already noticed that there's a bit of a problem? And wouldn't news of a giant bailout make these investors question Spanish finances as much as would news of debt restructuring?" (" 'Contagion' and other euro myths," Wall Street Journal, December 2, 2010).

Decision theory in the presence of model ambiguity focuses on two sources of misspecification: (i) model uncertainty conditional on the state, and (ii) uncertainty regarding the correct posterior distribution of the state itself. The first channel, preference for robustness regarding model parameters, has been more extensively studied in the literature. For example, it is well understood that, in a representative agent framework, the decision rule of a log-utility investor who uses an entropy penalty is observationally equivalent to that of an agent with recursive utility of the Epstein-Zin-Kreps-Porteus type (see, e.g., Barillas, Hansen, and Sargent 2009). However, the second channel, which can be interpreted as a preference for robustness toward misspecification in their beliefs, is less understood. One exception is the contemporaneous paper by Boyarchenko (2012) that investigates the impact of ambiguity aversion on the U.S. financial crisis of 2007-08.

The definition of rationality is perhaps debatable, since "fragile beliefs" preferences of Hansen and Sargent (2007, 2010) are not considered "mainstream." As we discuss below, these preferences represent only a small departure from the classic time-separable expected utility framework and are similar to using recursive utility of the Epstein-Zin (EZ) form. (Barillas, Hansen, and Sargent [2009] investigate the connection between recursive EZ utility and robust control.) Effectively, the model adds only one additional parameter, which governs tolerance to model misspecification, relative to the standard time-separable log utility. The advantage relative to using the more standard EZ preferences is that, in our context, fragile beliefs preferences are more tractable.
See, for example, Duffie et al. (2003), Edwards (1984), Hilscher and Nosbusch (2010), Longstaff et al. (2010), Min (1998), and Pan and Singleton (2008).

Collin-Dufresne, Goldstein, and Hugonnier (2004) simplify the bond-pricing formula of Duffie, Schroeder, and Skiadas (1996). Note, however, that the formula itself does not identify a tractable framework for pricing contagion risk. Other models of contagion include Davis and Lo (2001), Schönbucher and Schubert (2001), and Giesecke (2004).
See also Aït-Sahalia, Cacho-Diaz, and Laeven (Forthcoming), and Benzoni, Collin-Dufresne, and Goldstein (2011).

The updating equation for the posterior probability from the purely continuous signals (which obtains if dMt =0 above) is well known in the literature (e.g., Detemple 1986; Gennotte 1986; David 1997; and Veronesi 1999). The updating equation for the posterior probability of the state from pure jump signals (which obtains if dZt =0 in the above) follows from a direct application of Theorem 19.6 in Liptser and Shiryaev (2001, 332) (see also their example 1, p. 333).

This last result follows from the fact that we assumed the hidden state is fixed once and for all. It is possible to extend our contagion model construction to a time-varying hidden state, for example, that follows a continuous- time Markov chain, as in David (1997) and Veronesi (1999). This would make the uncertainty stationary. Instead, in our model investors will eventually learn the "true" model of the world, which in long data sets will introduce non-stationarity (e.g., in uncertainty premia). Given the relatively short time series we use in our empirical application, this is not an issue, however, so we focus here on the simpler case.
As we discuss in the online Appendix, using a time-separable utility function in the first step is closely related to time consistency and thus to the tractability of our model.

In the online Appendix we give an example of more general fragile beliefs preferences for which the state prices derived from the two-stage process give rise to dynamic arbitrage opportunities. In that example, the representative agent is not time-consistent. At time zero all claims, short- and long-dated, are valued such that she does not want to trade given his current and anticipated future consumption. However, at future dates, if markets reopen for trading at the prices consistent with time-zero state prices, the representative agent would like to trade, implying that the initial state prices do not support a no-trade equilibrium.

An alternative to having expected consumption growth carry a risk premium is to rely on long-run risk; see, e.g., Benzoni, Collin-Dufresne, and Goldstein (2011), Drechsler and Yaron (2011), and Eraker and Shaliastovich (2008). However, this setting no longer admits a closed-form solution.
See, e.g, Beber, Brandt, and Luisi (2014) for an alternative approach to extract factors from a panel dataset of macroeconomic news that help explain sovereign Euro-zone bond yields.

It is important to realize that Ç is not a scale-independent parameter, as its value depends on the particular normalization of the value function chosen. For instance, if we divide the conditional value function everywhere by ß, then the fragile beliefs value function (Equation (20)) is identical if we rewrite it in terms of £=£/£. Of course, except for the magnitude of the estimate of the tolerance parameter, none of the empirical predictions change. For example, the likelihood functions and the detection probabilities will be unchanged if we divide the value function by a constant.

With our current model specification absent model uncertainty there is no channel for time-varying risk premia. It would be interesting to extend the model to allow for distinct channels of time-varying risk and risk premia (such as long-run risk or habit formation) in addition to fragile beliefs. We leave this for future research.
Recent work by Bidder and McKenna (2014) and Breuer and Csiszâr (2013) incorporates robustness against misspecification of risk scenarios in stress tests for the banking system.

On October 27, 2011, euro-zone leaders agreed upon a new package of measures aimed at containing the crisis. The deal included a "voluntary" restructuring of Greek debt held by the private sector with a 50% haircut on the bonds' value. Yet, the International Swaps and Derivatives Association ruled that such "voluntary" renegotiation, no matter how much arm-twisting by European governments was involved, did not constitute a default event and, therefore, would not trigger CDS protection. These events cast doubt on the effectiveness of CDS contract as a means to hedge sovereign default risk. This legal uncertainty could add yet another component to the CDS basis.
